subject: Re: [junit] test cases for inputs from file
msgSnippet: In the cases where I *have* to use a file, the built-in java temp file generators work pretty well for getting a uniquely-built file every time.
messageBody:
In the cases where I *have* to use a file, the built-in java temp file
generators work pretty well for getting a uniquely-built file every time.

On Sunday, September 8, 2002, at 11:14 AM, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> On a number of occasions I have written a TestCase where setUp()
> creates an object that uses the file system and tearDown() clears the
> entire tree used by that object. I have never successfully had
> tearDown() finish before setUp() started for the next test, owing to
> the fact (I suppose) that the JVM does not block on the system call.
>
> I ended up doing what you suggest: I use a different root directory for
> each test, usually calling it something like
>
> root-<testClassName>-<testName>
>
> I then add a shutdown hook to clean them all up.
>
> Has anyone used Prevayler? If so, have you come up with any strategies
> for unit testing against the Prevayler without changing its source? I
> have been considering refactoring Prevayler to talk to byte streams and
> having one wrapper around it that uses the file system for production
> and another wrapper that keeps everything in memory for test.
>
> *********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********
>
> On 2002-09-07 at 17:37 Andrew Forward wrote:
>
>> I am curious under what circumstances the file ssytem is too slow to
>> clean up after itself?
>>
>> I have some code that crawls files and directories, so to test this
>> functionality I create the hierachy right in the TestCase. I use a
>> special createFile(...) method to, of course, create the file, as well
> as
>> track it in a Vector to be cleaned up on every tearDown();
>>
>> Would it be better to increment the root directory name and then
> delete
>> all the structures at the end of all test cases? Or would this
> present a
>> similar problem when joining multiple tests from multiple test classes
>> (provided they also access the file system in a similar manner).
>>
>> andrew f
>>
>> ```````````````````````
>> A common idea is to kill a folder on the file system after every test,
> in
>> order to start with a "clean slate". Unfortunately, the
>> tests are too fast for the file system, so the file system isn't clean
>> before the next test starts.
>> ```````````
>>
>>
